awd_titl_txt: RUI: Diffusion of Cyclodexrtrins and Cyclodextrin Polymeric Nanoparticles in Mucus Studied by 19F Diffusion NMR
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Yong Ba of the California State University at Los Angeles will employ nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) techniques to explore the diffusion of large molecules and polymeric nanoparticles in viscous liquids approximating biological mucus media. NMR diffusion studies will focus on fluorinated adamantane enclosed in different cyclodextrins in mucus models. The fluorinated adamantane will enable the exploration via the NMR active 19F nucleus, and diffusion parameters will be extracted using pulsed-field gradient techniques. The research will also involve the synthesis of cyclodextrin derivatives; characterization of these will entail mass spectrometric, proton NMR, and light scattering techniques. 

Cyclodextrin has potential as drug delivery vehicle, and an understanding of its diffusion properties across materials resembling nasal or gastrointestinal membranes is thus desirable. The PI will heavily rely on student contributions to research from the large pool of students from underrepresented minority groups at CSULA.  Students involved in this research will have access to a modern NMR facility, where they will be introduced not only to specialized diffusion techniques, but  conventional 1D and 2D NMR experiments as well.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: California State L A University Auxiliary Services Inc.

por.por_cntn:
A family of truncated cone shaped molecules called cyclodextrins are
valuable for industries, especially for formulating drugs in pharmaceutical
industry. Cyclodextrins act as carriers for delivering drugs because the
cavities of cyclodextrins can host or partially host drugs or other molecular
entities that we call guest molecules for a number of good purposes. For
example, cyclodextrins can increase the water solubility, stability and bioavailability of drugs. My research group has developed a model system in using fluorine-19 nuclear magnetic resonance diffusion method to study how beta-cyclodextrins diffuse through mucus. Mucus is a complex, viscous, adherent secretion that lines all the organs exposed to the external environment. Mucus serves as the first barrier with which nutrients and enteric drugs must interact with and diffuse through in order to gain access to the circulatory system. Thus, results of this project are significant in modifying beat-cyclodextrin for the purpose of improving its pharmaceutical properties. We have constructed kinetic model to assess which beta-cyclodextrins move faster in mucus and used models of hydrogel system to understand the mucus structure and the movement of beta-cyclodextrins. Eventually, we successfully modified beta-cyclodextrin using water soluble and biocompatible materials. Our diffusion study shows that the modification can hide beta-cyclodextrin molecules from direct interaction with mucus and the materials used have less interactions with mucus than beta-cyclodextrins. Thus, the modified beta-cyclodextrins can potentially improve a lot of properties of beta-cyclodextrin including water solubility; biocompatibility; blood circulation time; bioavailability; nontoxicity, non-immunogenicity, drug stability and controlled drug release. The potential impact on pharmaceutical industry, thus the improvement for human health are on the way.     

Graduate students and undergraduates have received tremendous research
training through doing this project. Two graduate students involved in this project have successfully graduated with Master Degrees in Chemistry. They have been contributing to the growth of pharmaceutical industry and developing entrepreneurship for the future economy of the US.



 

 


Last Modified: 10/15/2015
Modified by: Yong Ba
